message_1: What single replacement reaction occurs when copper is added to silver nitrate solution? Write the equation for the reaction and explain your observations.
message_2:
When copper is added to a silver nitrate solution, a single replacement reaction occurs. Copper is more reactive than silver, so it displaces silver from the silver nitrate solution. The equation for the reaction is:

Cu(s) + 2AgNO₃(aq) → Cu(NO₃)₂(aq) + 2Ag(s)

In this reaction, solid copper (Cu) reacts with aqueous silver nitrate (AgNO₃) to form aqueous copper(II) nitrate (Cu(NO₃)₂) and solid silver (Ag). 

Observations:
1. The color of the solution changes from colorless to blue, indicating the formation of copper(II) nitrate.
2. Silver metal precipitates out of the solution and may appear as a grayish-white solid or deposit on the surface of the copper.
3. The copper metal may gradually dissolve or become smaller in size as it is replaced by the silver precipitate.
